title: How to Move a Yard Ramp

steps.headline: Obtain a tow bar and connect the hook of the tow bar to the lower end of the yard ramp where you see an indentation that looks like a keyhole.
steps.description: The tow bar should fit like a key in a hole.

steps.headline: Connect the other end of the tow bar to a forklift on the rear side.
Drive the forklift to where you want the yard ramp, pulling the yard ramp behind you.
steps.description: The yard ramp can only move at less than 3 mph (4.8 km/h).

steps.headline: Stop the forklift and detach the tow bar.
To move the yard ramp up and down, move it into a loading dock, or back of a truck, use a ramp clamp.
Put the fork of the forklift in to the ramp clamp.
Raise the forks of the forklift and lower the ramp into place into the loading dock or tractor trailer.
Back the yard ramp out of the clamp.
Remove the ramp clamp.
steps.description: Your yard ramp is now positioned horizontally.

text: Moving a Short Distance Obtain a tow bar and connect the hook of the tow bar to the lower end of the yard ramp where you see an indentation that looks like a keyhole. The tow bar should fit like a key in a hole. Connect the other end of the tow bar to a forklift on the rear side.  Drive the forklift to where you want the yard ramp, pulling the yard ramp behind you. The yard ramp can only move at less than 3 mph (4.8 km/h). Stop the forklift and detach the tow bar.  Using Ramp Clamp To move the yard ramp up and down, move it into a loading dock, or back of a truck, use a ramp clamp.  Put the fork of the forklift in to the ramp clamp.  Get into the forklift.  Raise the forks of the forklift and lower the ramp into place into the loading dock or tractor trailer.  Get out of the forklift.  Back the yard ramp out of the clamp.  Remove the ramp clamp. Your yard ramp is now positioned horizontally.
